skills.name: Raise a positive integer to a positive integer power
Raise a number to the power of 0
Multiplication law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number
Division law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number
Calculate questions involving the power law of indices with positive integer powers

explanations.A: I think you have confused powers and multiples. A power of 5 is found by multiplying multiple copies of 5 together.
explanations.B: I think you have confused powers and multiples. A power of 5 is found by multiplying multiple copies of 5 together.
explanations.C: I think you have confused powers and multiples. A power of 5 is found by multiplying multiple copies of 5 together
explanations.D: 125 is a power of 5, as 125 = 5 x 5 x 5 = 5³ or '5 to the power of 3'.

explanations.A: I think you have confused powers and multiples. A power of 4 is found by multiplying multiple copies of 4 together.
explanations.B: 64 is a power of 4, as 64 = 4 x 4 x 4 = 4³ or '4 to the power of 3'.
explanations.C: I think you have confused powers and multiples. A power of 4 is found by multiplying multiple copies of 4 together.
explanations.D: I think you have confused powers and multiples. A power of 4 is found by multiplying multiple copies of 4 together.

explanations.A: I think you have written the power as a number. Try looking at 7 squared, 7 to the power of 1, and see what is happening each time you reduce the power by 1.
explanations.B: Any number to the power of 0 is 1.
explanations.C: I think you have multiplied by the power. Try looking at 7 squared, 7 to the power of 1, and see what is happening each time you reduce the power by 1.
explanations.D: This is 7 to the power of 1. Try looking at 7 squared, 7 to the power of 1, and see what is happening each time you reduce the power by 1.

explanations.A: This is 3 to the power of 1. Try looking at 3 cubed, 3 squared and 3 to the power of 1, and see what is happening each time you reduce the power by 1.
explanations.B: I think you have multiplied by 0. Try looking at 3 cubed, 3 squared and 3 to the power of 1, and see what is happening each time you reduce the power by 1.
explanations.C: Any number to the power of 0 is 1.
explanations.D: I think you wrote the power as a number. Try looking at 3 cubed, 3 squared and 3 to the power of 1, and see what is happening each time you reduce the power by 1.

explanations.A: We just need to add the powers, 4 and 3, to get 7.This is because we have 7 copies of 3 being multiplied: 3⁴ x 3³ = (3 x 3 x 3 x 3) x (3 x 3 x 3) = 3⁷.
explanations.B: I think you have multiplied the powers. Think about how many copies of 3 we will have multiplied together.
explanations.C: Almost, but we don't change the base number. Think about how many copies of 3 we have multiplied together.
explanations.D: Almost, but we don't change the base number. Think about how many copies of 3 we have multiplied together.

explanations.A: I think you have multiplied the powers and multiplied the base numbers. Think about how many copies of 2 we will have multiplied together.
explanations.B: I think you have multiplied the powers. Think about how many copies of 2 we will have multiplied together.
explanations.C: Almost, but we don't change the base number. Think about how many copies of 2 we have multiplied together.
explanations.D: We just need to add the powers, 5 and 2, to get 7.This is because we have 7 copies of 2 being multiplied together: 2⁵ x 2² = (2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 2) x (2 x 2) = 2⁷.

explanations.A: I think you have divided the powers. Think about how many copies of 2 you will have on the top and bottom of the fraction, and how many you can cancel out.
explanations.B: We have 10 copies of 2 multiplied on the top of the fraction, and 5 copies on the bottom. That means we can cancel out 5 copies, leaving 2⁵. We can also get this power by subtracting 5 from 10.
explanations.C: I think you have divided the base and the powers. Think about how many copies of 2 you will have on the top and bottom of the fraction, and how many you can cancel out.
explanations.D: I think you have subtracted the bases and divided the powers. Think about how many copies of 2 you will have on the top and bottom of the fraction, and how many you can cancel out.

explanations.A: We subtract the powers. 8 - 2 = 6 so we have 3⁶.This is because we have 8 copies of 3 being multiplied on the top of the fraction, and 2 copies on the bottom. That means we can cancel out 2 leaving 6 copies on the top.
explanations.B: I think you have divided the bases and the powers. Think about how many copies of 3 you will have on the top and bottom of the fraction, and how many you can cancel out.
explanations.C: I think you have divided the powers. Think about how many copies of 3 you will have on the top and bottom of the fraction, and how many you can cancel out.
explanations.D: I think you have subtracted the bases and divided the powers. Think about how many copies of 3 you will have on the top and bottom of the fraction, and how many you can cancel out.

explanations.A: We need to multiply the powers, 4 and 3, to get 12. So we get '5 to the power of 12' or 5¹².
explanations.B: I think you have added the powers. Remember (5⁴)³ means we have 3 copies of 5⁴ being multiplied. How many copies of 5 is this altogether?
explanations.C: I think you have cubed the 5. Remember (5⁴)³ means we have 3 copies of 5⁴ being multiplied. How many copies of 5 is this altogether?
explanations.D: The correct answer is here. Remember (5⁴)³ means we have 3 copies of 5⁴ being multiplied. How many copies of 5 is this altogether?

explanations.A: I think you have added the powers. Remember (4⁶)² means we have 2 copies of 4⁶ being multiplied. How many copies of 4 is this altogether?
explanations.B: I think you have squared the 4. Remember (4⁶)² means we have 2 copies of 4⁶ being multiplied. How many copies of 4 is this altogether?
explanations.C: We need to multiply the powers, 6 and 2, to get 12. So we get '4 to the power of 12' or 4¹².
explanations.D: The correct answer is here. Remember (4⁶)² means we have 2 copies of 4⁶ being multiplied. How many copies of 4 is this altogether?
